qas.question: How long did the Thuringian realm exist?
Which state was the largest in the region?

answers.text: the region between the Harz mountains in the north, the Weiße Elster river in the east, the Franconian Forest in the south and the Werra river in the west.

qas.question: Which dynasty formed after the Treaty of Leipzig?
Which Prussian territories joined Thuringia in 1945?

answers.text: Prussian territories around Erfurt, Mühlhausen and Nordhausen

qas.question: How long did the Thuringian realm decay?
Which state was the most dangerous in the region?
Which dynasty formed before the Treaty of Leipzig?

plausible_answers.text: territories around Erfurt, Mühlhausen and Nordhausen

qas.question: Which Prussian territories joined Thuringia in 1942?

plausible_answers.text: the region between the Harz mountains in the north, the Weiße Elster river in the east, the Franconian Forest in the south and the Werra river in the west

context: The Thuringian Realm existed <a0_0><b5_0>until 531 and later<b5_0/><a0_0/>, <a1_0><b6_0>the Landgraviate of Thuringia<b6_0/><a1_0/> was the largest state in the region, persisting between 1131 and 1247. Afterwards there was no state named Thuringia, nevertheless the term commonly described <a2_0><b9_0>the region between the Harz mountains in the north, the Weiße Elster river in the east, the Franconian Forest in the south and the Werra river in the west<b9_0/>.<a2_0/> After the Treaty of Leipzig, Thuringia had its own dynasty again, <a3_0><b7_0>the Ernestine Wettins<b7_0/><a3_0/>. Their various lands formed the Free State of Thuringia, founded in 1920, together with some other small principalities. The <a4_0>Prussian <b8_0>territories around Erfurt, Mühlhausen and Nordhausen<b8_0/><a4_0/> joined Thuringia in 1945.
